content: The Act titled "American Research and Competitiveness Act of 2014" simplifies and makes permanent the research credit. The American Research and Competitiveness Act of 2014 simplifies and makes permanent the research credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The research credit for the taxable year is determined as a percentage of qualified research expenses, basic research payments, and amounts paid or incurred by the taxpayer in carrying on any trade or business. The American Research and Competitiveness Act of 2014 simplifies and makes permanent the research credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes provisions for contributions to an energy research consortium for energy research and repeals the termination of Section 41. Conforming amendments are made to determine average research expenses for prior years. The qualified research expenses and basic research payments taken into account in determining such averages shall be determined on a basis consistent with the determination of qualified research expenses and basic research payments, respectively, for the credit year. The Secretary may prescribe regulations to prevent distortions in calculating a taxpayer's qualified research expenses or basic research payments due to changes in accounting methods. The IRS allows corporations to deduct cash payments made to qualified organizations for basic research, as long as there is a written agreement in place and the research is conducted by the organization.
